properties.Name: InventoryValuationMethod
properties.Description:
The method selected by the company to account for inventory. 

It determines the value of inventory on the balance sheet and the amount of expense recognized for cost of goods sold on the income statement.

The 3 most frequently used are:

- FIFO (First In/First Out)
The method of valuing inventory which assumes that all issues or sales are charged at the most current cost but inventory are valued at the latest cost available.

- LIFO (Last In/First Out) - Not permitted under IFRS
The method of valuing inventory which assumes that all issues or sales are charged at the most current cost but inventory are valued at the oldest cost available.

- Average Cost
The method of valuing inventory which is based on the average cost of the Item over a period of time.

Other methods include:
- Periodic Method
- Perpetual Method
- Weighted Average
- Specific Identification
- Net Realizable Value
- Lower Of Cost Or Market (LCM)
- LCM - Item by Item
- LCM - Total Replacement Cost
- Gross Profit Method
- Retail Inventory Method

Columns.Name: InventoryValuationMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Inventory Valuation Method.

Columns.Name: InventoryValuationMethodName
Columns.Description: The name of an Inventory Valuation Method.

Columns.Name: InventoryValuationMethodDescription
Columns.Description: The description of an Inventory Valuation Method.

Properties.Description:
The method selected by the company to account for inventory. 

It determines the value of inventory on the balance sheet and the amount of expense recognized for cost of goods sold on the income statement.

The 3 most frequently used are:

- FIFO (First In/First Out)
The method of valuing inventory which assumes that all issues or sales are charged at the most current cost but inventory are valued at the latest cost available.

- LIFO (Last In/First Out) - Not permitted under IFRS
The method of valuing inventory which assumes that all issues or sales are charged at the most current cost but inventory are valued at the oldest cost available.

- Average Cost
The method of valuing inventory which is based on the average cost of the Item over a period of time.

Other methods include:
- Periodic Method
- Perpetual Method
- Weighted Average
- Specific Identification
- Net Realizable Value
- Lower Of Cost Or Market (LCM)
- LCM - Item by Item
- LCM - Total Replacement Cost
- Gross Profit Method
- Retail Inventory Method
